title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Who am I?







I am the inaugural director of the Dominguez Center for Data Science at Bucknell University.

This is my first administrative gig.

We are building it up to be the campus hub for data science practice, support, and community.
I also spend my days figuring out our relationship to AI.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science
text:
Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science

Have had sabbaticals with

The Forest Service Forest Inventory and Analysis Program
The Bureau of Labor Statistics

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science
text: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Some Reflections





I have been on the job market a few times and so have thoughts on how to put together a good packet.
Happy to compare and contrast the different roles I’ve held:

Assistant to associate professor at small liberal arts colleges
Teaching faculty at a research university
Administrator for a data science center

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Some Reflections





It is okay to move and it is okay to stay.

Don’t strive for the perfect fit.

The people you work with regularly are important.

You have less control over your departmental colleagues.
You have more control over your research collaborators.

Choose your service commitments wisely.

Make sure to check the Schedule page often.


Gradescope:


For turning in work.


Slack for course communication.

Make sure to check Slack at least once a day during the work week.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Learning Objectives
You will engage in collaborative, data science projects. Upon successful completion of this course, you will be able to:

Conduct a full data analysis project.
Communicate about your data work at a variety of levels and via a variety of formats including short presentations, longer presentations, and written reports.
Think statistically about data and research questions.
Collaborate on projects with a reproducible workflow.
Run a productive consulting meeting.
Undertake future projects with greater independence.

title: DATA/MATH 306

Research Tools

Will vary by project!
All have access to an RStudio Server via a Posit Cloud Workspace. Will use for some activities and demos.
We will use a GitHub Organization for collaborating and to ensure we have a version controlled workflow.

Make sure to become a Watcher of the course site.
I will also share a specific project site with each student.

Bring a laptop to class. Please check-in with me if this will be an issue.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Readings

We will read a variety of papers and book chapters.
Main textbook is “Communicating with Data: The Art of Writing for Data Science” by Deborah Nolan and Sara Stoudt.

There are extra copies in Taylor 212. These copies should NOT leave Taylor 212.

Readings will be posted to the schedule.

Reading reflections are due Mondays at 10pm.

First reflections are due Sept 1st. Will discuss in Thursday’s class.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Policies

Make sure to check the course site for policies related to regrades, late work, attendance, technology, accommodations.
But let’s talk AI…

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
AI Policy
While A.I. tools, such as ChatGPT, are being used to generate code, analyze data, and write essays, goals of this course are to develop your own ability to write code, to thoughtfully extract knowledge from data, and to communicate your findings.
You may use AI in these course activities:

Providing feedback on their writing. The original draft should be your work but you can ask for feedback from AI and incorporate that feedback into the revision.
Providing coding suggestions or revisions. You are responsible for understanding every line of code in your project, regardless of whether it was written by you, your project members, your mentor, or AI.
Brainstorming ideas for your project.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
AI Policy
You may not use AI in these ways:

Writing the initial draft or whole paragraphs of a writing assignment or your technical report.
Writing large blocks of code.


If you do use AI in your project or on an assignment, please include an AI citation that provides: prompt, AI tool, company, date.


If you are in doubt as to whether you are using AI appropriately in this course, I encourage you to meet with me for a discussion. Violations of this policy will be considered academic misconduct.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Projects
Each project charter has:

Team composition: Student researchers will be assigned later this week.

Project goals: What the stakeholder mentor wants to accomplish.
Data: A brief description of the data for the project.
Desired deliverables: Vary by project but all include a well-documented repository, technical report, and a final presentation (Dec 15th 9am - 11am).
Roles and expectations for each person on the team.
Research plan
Communication


Please read over the project charters and complete the Background and Interest Survey by noon tomorrow!

Why Positron?










Positron is a new data science tool for writing code and exploring data.
You can use R or Python.
Go here to download R. (I will also show you how to interact with Python but the demos will be in R today.)
Go here to download Positron.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
DATA 306 git Experience










It takes some time to get comfortable with git. We have time.
Use office hours if you get stuck on any of the steps today!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
git and GitHub



git: Version control system

Think fancier type of Track Changes.

GitHub: Hosting service for git projects (which are called repositories)

Think fancier type of DropBox or Google Drive.

Useful resource when getting started: https://happygitwithr.com/

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Manual Version Control



But I already do version control…

draft.Rmd, draft2.Rmd, final.Rmd, realFinal.Rmd, REALLYVERYREALFinal.Rmd…

Issues with this version of version control:

Hard to know how these files relate.
Hard to extend this approach to working with others.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git Real

Git is a decentralized version control system.

Each collaborator has a complete version of the repo.
Everyone can work offline and simultaneously.
GitHub holds the master copy.

git is not friendly and can be frustrating.

BUT, the version control and collaborative rewards are big!

GitHub.com is a great place to develop an online presence.

In DATA 306, we will default to keeping the work private.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
A Hot Mess is Okay

If you end up with a mess of errors, then don’t worry but come see one of the instructors for help.

It happens to everyone.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: A Github Repo = Project/Folder on Your Computer
text:
A Github Repo = Project/Folder on Your Computer

A repo, short for repository, is the folder that contains all of the files for the project on GitHub.com.
Under the Bucknell-DATA306-F25 GitHub Organization you will have access to 3 repos:

work-username: Just you and I can access
class-site: The whole class can access
projectname: Your team, stakeholder (possibly), and I can access

For each repo, you should sync with a folder on your computer.

We will all do this together for work-username today.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Steps to Get Started


Once-Per-Computer/Server:

Install git on your computer.
Get your local git talking to GitHub.


Once-Per-Project:

Create a repo on GitHub.

I did this step for us.

Create a version controlled Project that is synced with the GitHub repo.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git via Positron + R

So that the workflow is the same for everyone:

Open Positron.
Start an R session.

You will be able to toggle to Python after we have synced with GitHub.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Check if git is install on your computer
text:
Check if git is install on your computer
In Terminal, type

which git

git --version





If you receive an answer, then git is already install! 🎉





If the reply is git: command not found (or similar), then

Windows: Visit https://gitforwindows.org/
Macs: In the Terminal type




xcode-select --install    



Restart your session.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Introduce Yourself to Git
Install the packages usethis and gitcreds:

install.packages(c("usethis", "gitcreds"))

In your R console, modify and run the following code to introduce yourself to git

usethis::use_git_config(user.name = "mcconvil", 
               user.email = "k.mcconville@bucknell.edu")

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Personal Access Token Time


To interact with GitHub, you need to include credentials.

Personal Access Token (PAT)

In your R console, run



usethis::create_github_token()



Should take you to GitHub.
Select “repo”, “user”, and “workflow” for the scopes.
Click “Generate token”.
Store it by running the following in the R Console:



gitcreds::gitcreds_set()

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Sync GitHub.com repo and a Project
text:
Sync GitHub.com repo and a Project
In your repo on GitHub.com:


Click on the green clone or download button.
Copy the given url for “Clone with HTTPS”.


In Positron:


In the Welcome pane, select “New from Git…”
Paste in the url.
Select “Browse…” and select a logical place on your computer for the repository folder.
Hit the “OK” button.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Workflow
Once your GitHub repo and RStudio project are synced, here’s your workflow:

On the left menu, select “Source Control”.
Under the three dots associated with “CHANGES”, select Pull.

This will pull the most recent version of the repo from GitHub to your local folder.

Do some work on your project and save it.
In the “Source Control”, select the “+” (stage changes) button.
Include a quick note, Commit Message to summarize the motivation for the changes.
Select Commit & Push to send your work to GitHub.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Test the waters: Let’s go through the workflow.
text:
Test the waters: Let’s go through the workflow.


Pull. (Yes, there is nothing to pull yet but it is always good practice to start here.)
Click on the ReadMe.
Add something to the ReadMe.
Stage the changes to the ReadMe.
Put in a commit message.
Commit & Push.


Look for updates in the ReadMe on GitHub.com.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git Collaboration: Merge conflicts

What if my collaborators and I both make changes?

Scenario: Your collaborator makes changes to a file, commits, and pushes to GitHub. You also modify that file, commit and push.

Result: Your push will fail because there’s a commit on GitHub that you don’t have.

Usual Solution: Pull and usually git will merge their work nicely with yours. Then push. If that doesn’t work, you have a merge conflict. Let’s cross that bridge when we get there.

How to avoid merge conflicts?

Always pull when you are going to work on your project.
Always commit and push when you are done even if you made small changes.
